Posts.Content: I’m in Hereford where we have a small district hospital who don’t seem to take much notice of Macmillan/NICE. They faffed around so much after two inadequate lumpectomies that I felt I couldn’t wait any longer and accepted what they offered, immediate mastectomy and implant with expander. I do have a referral in now to Birmingham for a later reconstruction either Diep or Tram. Need to get results first, and find out whether or not I will need radiotherapy   I thought I was getting on well, just one drain in, then I accidentally tugged on it tonight and it’s really sore. Hopefully I’ll get them to remove it tomorrow. My own fault really.  Hope you are still doing ok x
Posts.Title: Post op bras

Posts.Content: Hi Rolybun, I had my  mastectomy eight days ago, and like you was advised to wear sports bras. The problem is, my un-operated boob is 44DD, and the operated one with a expandable implant appears to be about half that size, and mostly under my armpit!   So, any type of bra just gapes over the one that had the operation, and will clearly not be giving any support. I found in Sainsbury’s some crop tops that go up to my size, and they seem the best option for now. Not quite comfortable enough to wear in bed, but okay the rest of the day, giving some support on both sides.  Did your hospital give you a reduction at the same time as the mastectomy? Mine were absolutely adamant they would not do that, so it looks as though I’m going to be living with asymmetry for quite some time.
Posts.Title: Post op bras

Posts.Content: Miserable, but does sound more like menopause than BC consequence. I had just got into menopause then BC hit me. Do ask for a gynaecologist referral you don’t have to put up with it. Good luck xx
Posts.Title: Chronic bleeding after months of nothing - help

Posts.Content: I had my mastectomy and expander implant in September. It all healed up relatively quickly, and apart from hating the shape of the implant, and the saggy skin under it that looked like a double chin, I thought I was doing fine. I had a couple of sessions to put saline in the implant, and stopped when the treated breast was just a little smaller than the other one. And then, just before Christmas, the treated breast swelled up quite badly. It felt very lumpy and tight. I went back to see the surgeon who said it was fluid, and was nothing to worry about. The BCN suggested I massaged it and kept doing my exercises, but this hasn’t made any difference. She also suggested that maybe I was wearing a bra with enough support, but at 42 D I was able to find very little that was comfortable, but did feel well supported. I was just wondering if anyone else had experienced this, and how long it took to go away.  Is there anything I can do to make it go quicker? I really don’t get on well with my surgeon, I find him patronising and dismissive, so I don’t want to go back to see him unless I absolutely have to. There is no redness or soreness so I’m pretty sure it’s not an infection. If it is like this much longer I feel inclined to ask for some of the saline to be removed. Has anyone had that done?  Has anyone had that done? I’m hoping to have the implant replaced by a DIEP in a year or so, I had decided just to ensure the implant until then, but it’s worse than I thought it would be.  I had decided just to ensure the implant until then, but it’s worse than I thought it would be. Any advice gratefully received.
Posts.Title: Swelling four months after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Thank you all for your replies. I contacted the breast cancer nurses at the hospital. I hope they would be able to see me themselves, but they sorted out an appointment with the consultant. He says there is a lot of fluid, probably because he left quite a lot of skin after the  mastectomy, apparently that will make it easier for the diep if I have that in the end. So in the short term he wasn’t worried, and in the longer term the nurses have arranged for me to see the oedema specialist. He said that taking liquid out of the implant might make things worse, by causing a bigger gap between my skin and the implant, which might just fill with more fluid. I think that all made sense, and I did feel slightly more listened to than on some of my appointments.  Before I will get a definite answer about the diep I have to lose some weight. So far I have lost 12 KG out of the target of 19, so I’m almost there. I will contact the regional centre where the diep would happen to see how soon they can complete my assessment. And if that turns out to go nowhere, I will probably have the temporary implant  removed sooner rather than later.  Nothing is straightforward, but at least  I am being taken seriously now.
Posts.Title: Swelling four months after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi, I ‘only‘ had DCIS, but it was quite widespread. Like you, I was surprised the first lumpectomy didn’t work. After a lot of thinking, I had a second lumpectomy, which also didn’t work, but at least it meant when I had the mastectomy I knew that was the only option. Looking back, I’m still glad I tried the second time. Good luck with your decision.
